title: 111_s2969
content: The Act may be cited as the "Homeowners' Relief and Neighborhood Stabilization Act of 2010" and includes provisions for emergency mortgage relief. The Secretary of the Treasury will transfer $3 billion to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development for the Emergency Homeowners' Relief Fund. This fund will provide emergency mortgage assistance in accordance with the Emergency Housing Act of 1975. The Secretary of the Treasury will transfer $3 billion to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development for the Emergency Homeowners' Relief Fund, which will provide emergency mortgage assistance. Amendments include certifying instead of indicating, removing specific loan volume references, and adding medical conditions to adverse economic conditions. The Emergency Homeowners' Relief Fund will provide assistance to homeowners with mortgage payments, capped at $50,000 per homeowner. The interest rate on insured loans will be fixed for the loan's duration. The Emergency Homeowners' Relief Fund will provide assistance to homeowners with mortgage payments, capped at $50,000 per homeowner. The interest rate on loans will not exceed the rate charged for mortgages on single-family housing insured by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. No interest will be charged on deferred interest for loans made under this title. The Secretary will consider a homeowner's ability to repay when establishing loan terms. The Emergency Homeowners' Relief Fund allows eligible homeowners to repay grants or credit advances without penalty before the loan is due. Changes are made to section 105, including increasing the limit to $3 billion and adding emergency mortgage relief payments. The Secretary will establish guidelines for allocating funds for loans and relief payments based on the likelihood of mortgagors resuming payments. Section 107 is amended by removing subsection (a) and (b), while section 108 adds a new subsection allowing funds to be administered by states with existing programs. The Secretary will establish guidelines for allocating funds for loans and relief payments based on mortgagors' likelihood of resuming payments. Section 108 allows funds to be administered by states with existing programs deemed substantially similar by the Secretary. Sections 110, 111, and 113 are removed, and section 112 is redesignated as section 110. SEC. 3. ADDITIONAL ASSISTANCE FOR NEIGHBORHOOD STABILIZATION PROGRAM. The Secretary of the Treasury will transfer $1 billion to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development for assistance in redeveloping abandoned and foreclosed homes, following provisions from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. Amounts made available by this section shall remain available until expended and shall be allocated based on a funding formula established by the Secretary in accordance with the Housing and Economic Recovery Act of 2008. The provisos of the second undesignated paragraph shall not apply to these amounts, and the Secretary is required to establish the formula within 30 days of the enactment of this Act without setting any minimum grant amount for States. The Secretary may establish a minimum grant amount for direct allocations to local governments, not exceeding $1,000,000. States and local governments must create preferences for affordable rental housing development. Certain provisions of the Housing and Economic Recovery Act of 2008 do not apply to the grant amounts provided in this section. The Housing and Economic Recovery Act of 2008 provisions do not apply to amounts made available in this section. The definition of "State" includes various territories for this section. Amounts from this section cannot be distributed to certain entities. The provision prohibits distribution of funds to organizations convicted of election-related violations or employing individuals convicted of such violations. Applicable individuals are defined as those employed, contracted, or acting on behalf of the organization, and convicted of election-related violations.
